explanation:
To determine if lines are parallel or perpendicular, their slopes must satisfy either \( m_1 = m_2 \) (parallel) or \( m_1 \cdot m_2 = -1 \) (perpendicular). The lines are non-intersecting and converge, ruling out both parallel and perpendicular relationships. 

The student likely observed the lines' visual orientation (closer at one end) and misinterpreted this convergence as an intersection forming a 90° angle. They assumed the apparent angle created by the lines' positions must be a right angle, despite the lines never actually intersecting. This directly aligns with misjudging angles based on visual approximation rather than mathematical criteria. 

The error is distinct from not knowing the definition of perpendicular (which requires intersection) or assuming right angles must align with axes. Instead, the flaw stems from conflating perceived angles with actual geometric relationships, bypassing slope analysis.
